intro: Pauridia maximiliani, commonly known as the Mexican moonflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its large, white, fragrant flowers that open at night. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are ovate and slightly hairy, while its fruits are small, berry-like capsules containing numerous seeds. Pauridia maximiliani is often cultivated for its ornamental value and nocturnal blooming habit.
